body:
Why should it be longer for the diff? I thought the point of this was to be
constant time. It does not appear to be that way. I suspect it is doing a
fast initial.comparison that fails for the different strings and falls back
on a slower version.  For example, it might attempt a byte by byte
comparison and then failong that attempt a unicode character comparison.

We could certainly read the implementation of == to know for sure. In any
case, since constant time comparison is not part of =='s contract, we can't
use it.

- Charlie (mobile)
On Feb 9, 2013 4:06 PM, "Andrew White" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @headius <https://github.com/headius> your reasoning is correct, however
> the large difference you're seeing is down to the fact that val1 and val2
> are the same object so the comparison is being short circuited - if you
> change val2 to be val2 = val1.dup then the result is much closer. The
> comparison for the same string should take longer than the one that differs
> in the first character.
